## Project Description

From the [STA 9750 Course Assignment Page](https://michael-weylandt.com/STA9750/miniprojects/mini01.html):

> *"You are a data analyst at Netflix, tasked with supporting the Public Relations team. As you may know, Netflix continues to invest heavily in original television and film content, with the goal of producing successful “gourmet cheeseburgers”, i.e., high-quality content that is still accessible to and popular with a global mass-market audience. Accordingly, the PR team wants to put out a series of press releases highlighting recent successes. In this project, you will mine Netflix’s public Top 10 data to identify and quantify these successes."*

## Methodology
This report is using data obtained from Netflix streaming data. 

**Data Acquisition**
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Data Download Code"
if(!dir.exists(file.path("data", "mp01"))){
    dir.create(file.path("data", "mp01"), showWarnings=FALSE, recursive=TRUE)
}

GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "global_top10_alltime.csv")

if(!file.exists(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-global.tsv", 
                  destfile=GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}

COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME <- file.path("data", "mp01", "country_top10_alltime.csv")

if(!file.exists(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)){
    download.file("https://www.netflix.com/tudum/top10/data/all-weeks-countries.tsv", 
                  destfile=COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME)
}
```

**Data Import and Preparation**
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Data Library Code"
#| output: false
library(tidyverse)
library(DT)
library(stringr)
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Data Import Code"
#| output: false
GLOBAL_TOP_10 <- read_tsv(GLOBAL_TOP_10_FILENAME)
COUNTRY_TOP_10 <- read_tsv(COUNTRY_TOP_10_FILENAME, na = "N/A")
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Data Cleaning Code"
GLOBAL_TOP_10 <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
mutate(season_title = if_else(season_title == "N/A", NA_character_, season_title))
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Data Verification Code"
#| output: false
glimpse(GLOBAL_TOP_10)
glimpse(COUNTRY_TOP_10)
```

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Helper Function Code"
format_titles <- function(df){
  colnames(df) <- str_replace_all(colnames(df), "_", " ") |> str_to_title()
  df
}
```

# Netflix Global Top 10
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Code"
GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  mutate(`runtime_(minutes)` = round(60 * runtime)) |>
  select(-season_title, -runtime) |>
  format_titles() |>
  head(n=20) |>
  datatable(options=list(searching=FALSE, info=FALSE)) |>
  formatRound(c('Weekly Hours Viewed', 'Weekly Views'))
```

# Exploratory Questions 
Key questions were used to guide the data analysis process.

### 1: How many countries does Netflix operate in?
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Country Analysis Code"

num_countries <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  distinct(country_name) |>
  nrow()

top_countries <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  group_by(country_name) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Entries = n(),
    Unique_Shows = n_distinct(show_title)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Entries)) |>
  slice_head(n = 20) |>
  rename(
    Country = country_name,
    `Total Top 10 Entries` = Total_Entries,
    `Unique Shows in Top 10` = Unique_Shows
  )

top_countries |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold;',
      'Top 20 Countries by Top 10 Appearances'
    )
  )
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
Netflix operates in **`r num_countries` different countries** worldwide. They are a global leader in the entertainment business and offer streaming services and original content across the globe.
:::

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Map Code"
#| warning: false

library(plotly)

# Prepare data
netflix_map_data <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  distinct(country_name) |>
  mutate(
    status = "Netflix Available",
    value = 1
  )

# Create choropleth
plot_geo(netflix_map_data) |>
  add_trace(
    locations = ~country_name,
    locationmode = "country names",
    z = ~value,
    text = ~country_name,
    colors = "#E50914",
    showscale = FALSE,
    hoverinfo = "text"
  ) |>
  layout(
    title = list(
      text = "Netflix Operating Countries",
      font = list(size = 16)
    ),
    geo = list(
      projection = list(type = "robinson"),
      showframe = FALSE,
      showcoastlines = TRUE,
      coastlinecolor = "#444444"
    )
  )
```

### 2: Which non-English film has spent the most weeks in the global top 10?
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Non-English Film Analysis Code"

# Find top non-English films by weeks in Top 10
top_non_english_films <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(category == "Films (Non-English)") |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Weeks = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Weeks)) |>
  slice_head(n = 10) |>
  rename(
    `Film Title` = show_title,
    `Weeks in Top 10` = Total_Weeks
  )

# Get the top film info
film_name <- top_non_english_films$`Film Title`[1]
weeks_count <- top_non_english_films$`Weeks in Top 10`[1]

# Display table
top_non_english_films |>
  datatable(
caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
  style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
  'Top 10 Non-English Films by Weeks in Global Top 10'
),
    options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = FALSE)
  )
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
**`r film_name`** is the non-English film wiht the most cumulative weeks in the global Top 10. The German film premiered in 2022 and spent **`r weeks_count` weeks** total in the global Top 10. 

The film is based on the famous 1929 German novel, written by  Erich Maria Remarque, and has a run time of 147 minutes. It received positive critical receiption and won numerous awards, including Academy Awards for Best Production Design and Best Cinematography.

### 3: What is the longest film to have appeared in the Netflix global Top 10?
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Longest Films Analysis Code"

# Create the table - filter for FILMS only
longest_films <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(!is.na(runtime)) |>
  filter(category == "Films (English)" | category == "Films (Non-English)") |>
  group_by(show_title, category) |>
  summarise(
    Runtime_Minutes = round(mean(runtime * 60)),
    Best_Position = min(weekly_rank),
    Weeks_in_Top_10 = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Runtime_Minutes)) |>
  slice_head(n = 10) |>
  rename(
    `Film Title` = show_title,
    Category = category,
    `Runtime (minutes)` = Runtime_Minutes,
    `Best Top 10 Position` = Best_Position,
    `Weeks in Top 10` = Weeks_in_Top_10
  )

# Get answer from the table
film_name <- longest_films$`Film Title`[1]
runtime_minutes <- longest_films$`Runtime (minutes)`[1]

# Display table
longest_films |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
      'Top 10 Longest Films in Netflix Global Top 10'
    ),
    options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = FALSE)
  )
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
**`r film_name`** is the longest film to appear in the Netflix global Top 10, with a runtime of **`r runtime_minutes` minutes** (3 hours and 44 minutes). The 2024 Telugu-language film is part of India's Tollywood cinema. The action drama is a sequal to the 2021 film, Pushpa: The Rise. The Reloaded Version topping this list for length is 24 minutes longer than the film's original release.

*Note that Netflix does not provide runtime data for all programs, particularly older entries.*

### Content Spotlight: Netflix India

India is the most populated country in the world and represents a major growth opportunity for Netflix. The company has continued to see high performance and invest in original programming in this region.

![](https://dazeinfo.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/netflix-india-2022-lineup-1.webp){width=80%}

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show India Viewership Analysis Code"
#| warning: false

# Note: COUNTRY_TOP_10 does not have viewership hours data
# We can only analyze by weeks in Top 10 and rankings

india_by_category <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "India") |>
  group_by(category) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Entries = n(),
    Unique_Titles = n_distinct(show_title),
    Total_Weeks = n_distinct(week),
    Avg_Cumulative_Weeks = mean(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Entries)) |>
  rename(
    Category = category,
    `Total Top 10 Entries` = Total_Entries,
    `Unique Titles` = Unique_Titles,
    `Weeks with Data` = Total_Weeks,
    `Avg Cumulative Weeks` = Avg_Cumulative_Weeks
  )

india_by_category |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold;',
      'India Market Performance by Content Category'
    ),
    options = list(paging = FALSE, searching = FALSE)
  )
```

### Top 10 Most Popular Titles in India
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Top 10 India Titles"
#| warning: false

# Top 10 titles by total weeks in India's Top 10
india_top_titles <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "India") |>
  group_by(show_title, category) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Weeks = n(),
    Best_Rank = min(weekly_rank),
    Max_Cumulative_Weeks = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Weeks)) |>
  slice_head(n = 10) |>
  mutate(Rank = row_number()) |>
  select(Rank, show_title, category, Total_Weeks, Best_Rank, Max_Cumulative_Weeks) |>
  rename(
    `Title` = show_title,
    `Category` = category,
    `Weeks in Top 10` = Total_Weeks,
    `Best Rank Achieved` = Best_Rank,
    `Peak Cumulative Weeks` = Max_Cumulative_Weeks
  )

india_top_titles |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
      'Top 10 Most Popular Titles in India by Weeks in Top 10'
    ),
    options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = FALSE, paging = FALSE)
  )
```

### India-Exclusive Titles: Popular in India but Not in US Top 10
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show India-Exclusive Titles Code"
#| warning: false

# Get titles that appeared in India
india_titles <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "India") |>
  distinct(show_title)

# Get titles that appeared in US
us_titles <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "United States") |>
  distinct(show_title)

# Find titles in India but not US
india_exclusive <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "India") |>
  filter(!show_title %in% us_titles$show_title) |>
  group_by(show_title, category) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Weeks = n(),
    Best_Rank = min(weekly_rank),
    Max_Cumulative_Weeks = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Weeks)) |>
  slice_head(n = 30) |>
  mutate(Rank = row_number()) |>
  select(Rank, show_title, category, Total_Weeks, Best_Rank, Max_Cumulative_Weeks) |>
  rename(
    `Title` = show_title,
    `Category` = category,
    `Weeks in India Top 10` = Total_Weeks,
    `Best Rank in India` = Best_Rank,
    `Peak Cumulative Weeks` = Max_Cumulative_Weeks
  )

india_exclusive |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
      'Top 30 Titles Popular in India but Not in US Top 10'
    ),
    options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = TRUE)
  )
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
These titles demonstrate strong local market appeal in India without charting in the US, highlighting Netflix's success with region-specific content that resonates with Indian audiences.
:::

### Content Longevity: India vs. Other Major Markets
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Longevity Comparison with Visualization Code"
#| warning: false

library(ggplot2)

# Calculate longevity metrics for major markets
longevity_data <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name %in% c("India", "United States", "United Kingdom", "Brazil", "Mexico", "Japan", "France", "Germany")) |>
  group_by(country_name, show_title) |>
  summarise(
    weeks_in_top_10 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  group_by(country_name) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Titles = n_distinct(show_title),
    Avg_Weeks = mean(weeks_in_top_10),
    Median_Weeks = median(weeks_in_top_10),
    Max_Weeks = max(weeks_in_top_10),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Create bar chart
ggplot(longevity_data, aes(x = reorder(country_name, Avg_Weeks), y = Avg_Weeks, fill = country_name)) +
  geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(Avg_Weeks, 1)), hjust = -0.2, size = 3.5) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(
    "India" = "#E50914",
    "United States" = "#564d4d",
    "United Kingdom" = "#564d4d",
    "Brazil" = "#564d4d",
    "Mexico" = "#564d4d",
    "Japan" = "#564d4d",
    "France" = "#564d4d",
    "Germany" = "#564d4d"
  )) +
  labs(
    title = "Average Content Longevity by Market",
    subtitle = "Average weeks titles stay in Top 10",
    x = "",
    y = "Average Weeks in Top 10"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 11, color = "gray40"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10)
  ) +
  ylim(0, max(longevity_data$Avg_Weeks) * 1.15)
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
The chart highlights India compared to other major markets. Average weeks per title indicates how long content typically remains popular in each market. These results suggest that India is a growing market for Netflix, with popular titles staying in the Top 10 longer than other countries.
:::


### 4: Which program has the most total hours of viewership in each category?
*The table below shows the top 5 programs in each category.*

::: {.panel-tabset}

## Films (English)
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Top 5 English Films Code"

top_english_films <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(category == "Films (English)") |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Hours_Viewed = sum(weekly_hours_viewed, na.rm = TRUE),
    Weeks_in_Top_10 = max(cumulative_weeks_in_top_10),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  slice_max(Total_Hours_Viewed, n = 5) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Hours_Viewed)) |>
  mutate(Rank = row_number()) |>
  rename(
    `Program Title` = show_title,
    `Total Hours Viewed` = Total_Hours_Viewed,
    `Weeks in Top 10` = Weeks_in_Top_10
  )

top_english_films |>
  datatable(
    options = list(paging = FALSE, searching = FALSE, dom = 't'),
    rownames = FALSE
  ) |>
  formatRound('Total Hours Viewed', digits = 0) |>
  formatStyle(
    'Rank',
    target = 'row',
    backgroundColor = styleEqual(1, '#d4edda')
  )
```

### 6: Netflix provides over 200 weeks of service history for all but one country in our data set. Which country is this and when did Netflix cease operations in that country?
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Country Service History Analysis Code"
#| warning: false

# Count weeks of data per country
country_weeks <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  group_by(country_name) |>
  summarise(
    Weeks_of_Data = n_distinct(week),
    First_Week = min(week),
    Last_Week = max(week),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(Weeks_of_Data)

# Find the country with fewer than 200 weeks
limited_country <- country_weeks |>
  filter(Weeks_of_Data < 200) |>
  slice_head(n = 1)

country_name <- limited_country$country_name
weeks_available <- limited_country$Weeks_of_Data
last_week <- limited_country$Last_Week
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
**`r country_name`** has only **`r weeks_available` weeks** of service history in the dataset. The last week of data for this country is **`r last_week`**, suggesting Netflix ceased operations there around that time.
:::

::: {.column-margin}
**Related:** [Netflix Suspends Service in Russia Following the Country's Invation of Ukraine (CNBC)](https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/06/netflix-suspends-service-in-russia.html)
:::

The table below shows all countries sorted by weeks of available data:

### 8: How many views did Red Notice (1hr 58min runtime) receive in 2021?
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Red Notice 2021 Viewership Code"
#| warning: false

library(lubridate)

# Red Notice runtime in hours
red_notice_runtime <- 1 + 58/60  # 1 hour 58 minutes = 1.967 hours

# Calculate views in 2021
red_notice_2021 <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(show_title == "Red Notice") |>
  filter(year(week) == 2021) |>
  summarise(
    Total_Hours_Viewed = sum(weekly_hours_viewed, na.rm = TRUE),
    Total_Weeks = n()
  )

# Calculate approximate views using runtime
total_hours <- red_notice_2021$Total_Hours_Viewed
approximate_views <- total_hours / red_notice_runtime
weeks_in_2021 <- red_notice_2021$Total_Weeks
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding
**Red Notice** received approximately **`r format(round(approximate_views), big.mark = ",")` views** in 2021.

*(Calculated from `r format(total_hours, big.mark = ",")` total hours viewed)*
:::

::: {.column-margin}
**Related:** [KPop Demon Hunters Beats Red Notice For the Most-Watched Film in Netflix History (MovieWeb)](https://movieweb.com/netflix-red-notice-replaced-by-kpop-demon-hunters-all-time-biggest-movie/)
:::

Detailed breakdown:
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Red Notice 2021 Weekly Data Code"
#| warning: false

red_notice_weekly <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(show_title == "Red Notice") |>
  filter(year(week) == 2021) |>
  mutate(
    Calculated_Views = round(weekly_hours_viewed / red_notice_runtime)
  ) |>
  select(week, weekly_rank, weekly_hours_viewed, Calculated_Views) |>
  rename(
    Week = week,
    Rank = weekly_rank,
    `Hours Viewed` = weekly_hours_viewed,
    `Estimated Views` = Calculated_Views
  )

red_notice_weekly |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
```

```{r}
global_climbers <- GLOBAL_TOP_10 |>
  filter(category %in% c("Films (English)", "Films (Non-English)")) |>
  arrange(show_title, week) |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(
    debut_rank = first(weekly_rank),
    ever_reached_1 = any(weekly_rank == 1),
    first_week_at_1 = if_else(any(weekly_rank == 1), 
                               min(week[weekly_rank == 1]), 
                               as.Date(NA)),
    weeks_at_1 = sum(weekly_rank == 1),
    category = first(category),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  filter(ever_reached_1 & debut_rank > 1) |>
  arrange(desc(first_week_at_1))

global_num <- nrow(global_climbers)
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Key Finding (Alternative Answer - Global Data)
**`r global_num` films** reached #1 in the **global** Top 10 without debuting at #1. The most recent was **`r if(global_num > 0) global_climbers$show_title[1] else "N/A"`**, which debuted at #`r if(global_num > 0) global_climbers$debut_rank[1] else "N/A"` and reached #1 on **`r if(global_num > 0) global_climbers$first_week_at_1[1] else "N/A"`**.

*Note: This analysis uses global Top 10 data rather than US-specific data due to data availability.*
:::
```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Global Films Table Code"
#| warning: false

if(global_num > 0) {
  global_climbers |>
    select(show_title, category, debut_rank, first_week_at_1, weeks_at_1) |>
    rename(
      `Film Title` = show_title,
      Category = category,
      `Debut Rank` = debut_rank,
      `First Week at #1` = first_week_at_1,
      `Weeks at #1` = weeks_at_1
    ) |>
    datatable(
      caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
        style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
        'Global Films That Climbed to #1 After Lower Debuts'
      ),
      options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = TRUE)
    )
}
```

### 10: Which TV show/season hit the top 10 in the most countries in its debut week?

::: {.callout-warning}
## Data Limitation
The COUNTRY_TOP_10 dataset does not contain TV show data - only films are tracked at the country level in this dataset. As demonstrated in Question 5, TV shows only appear in the GLOBAL_TOP_10 dataset. Due to this limitation, it is not possible to determine which TV show hit the most countries in its debut week in this report.
:::

::: {.column-margin}
**Related:**
According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squid_Game_season_3?utm_source=chatgpt.com) **Squid Game** ranked #1 in 93 countries in its debut week.
:::

::: {.callout-note}
## Alternative Analysis
Since country-level TV data is unavailable, to fully answer this question it would require Netflix's country-specific TV viewership data.

The global Top 10 data shows overall international performance but does not break down viewership by individual countries for TV shows.
:::

## Press Release #2 - Commercial Success in India

![](https://images.ctfassets.net/4cd45et68cgf/2LE7H5fpCAQdgcAwfB9V70/7aa53e72ad35d58d9850484e3c5ddfc0/Blog_16x9_Cover_3.png){width=65%}

#### **Netflix Continues to Invest in India, Following Brag-Worthy Market Performance**
*New York, NY - October, 2025*

Netflix is not slowing down its expansion in India any time soon. Following the launch of Netflix India in 2016, the streaming giant has seen tremendous success. A focus on localized content has led to Hindi-language titles like *The Great Indian Kapil Show*, a sketch comedy series, and *Mismatched*, a coming-of-age drama, ranking in the Top 10 for over 30 weeks total in India. These titles are among many top performing TV shows and films that ranked in the Top 10 in India, but not in the United States. This illustrates the strength of the Indian streaming audience as well as the value of Netflix investing in region-specific content. Moreover, data shows that content that has global appeal remains in the Top 10 longer in India (average of 3.8 weeks per title), than other major markets like Japan (3.2 weeks per title), Germany (2.9 weeks per title), the United States (2.7 weeks per title), and the United Kingdom (2.7 weeks per title).

*Netflix is a global leader in entertainment streaming. Netflix India launched in 2016 as part of an effort to expand its global user base. The company has put an emphasis on creating original programming to reflect the culture of the region.*


```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "Show Table Code"
#| warning: false

# Get top titles in India
india_top <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "India") |>
  group_by(show_title, category) |>
  summarise(
    India_Weeks = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(India_Weeks)) |>
  slice_head(n = 10)

# Get weeks in top 10 for other countries
us_weeks <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "United States") |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(US_Weeks = n(), .groups = "drop")

uk_weeks <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "United Kingdom") |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(UK_Weeks = n(), .groups = "drop")

japan_weeks <- COUNTRY_TOP_10 |>
  filter(country_name == "Japan") |>
  group_by(show_title) |>
  summarise(Japan_Weeks = n(), .groups = "drop")

# Combine all weeks
india_international <- india_top |>
  left_join(us_weeks, by = "show_title") |>
  left_join(uk_weeks, by = "show_title") |>
  left_join(japan_weeks, by = "show_title") |>
  mutate(
    Rank = row_number(),
    US_Weeks = ifelse(is.na(US_Weeks), 0, US_Weeks),
    UK_Weeks = ifelse(is.na(UK_Weeks), 0, UK_Weeks),
    Japan_Weeks = ifelse(is.na(Japan_Weeks), 0, Japan_Weeks)
  ) |>
  select(Rank, show_title, category, India_Weeks, US_Weeks, UK_Weeks, Japan_Weeks) |>
  rename(
    Title = show_title,
    Category = category,
    `India Weeks` = India_Weeks,
    `US Weeks` = US_Weeks,
    `UK Weeks` = UK_Weeks,
    `Japan Weeks` = Japan_Weeks
  )

india_international |>
  datatable(
    caption = htmltools::tags$caption(
      style = 'caption-side: top; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;',
      'Top 10 India Titles: Weeks in Top 10 by Country'
    ),
    options = list(pageLength = 10, searching = FALSE, paging = FALSE, scrollX = TRUE)
  )
```

